<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

Here is the code of MHD_bin_to_hex_z:
```c
size_t
MHD_bin_to_hex_z (const void *bin,
                  size_t size,
                  char *hex)
{
  size_t res;

  res = MHD_bin_to_hex (bin, size, hex);
  hex[res] = 0;

  return res;
```

<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_bin_to_hex_z:
size_t
MHD_bin_to_hex (const void *bin,
                size_t size,
                char *hex)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < size; ++i)
  {
    uint8_t j;
    const uint8_t b = ((const uint8_t *) bin)[i];
    j = b >> 4;
    hex[i * 2] = (char) ((j < 10) ? (j + '0') : (j - 10 + 'a'));
    j = b & 0x0f;
    hex[i * 2 + 1] = (char) ((j < 10) ? (j + '0') : (j - 10 + 'a'));
  }
  return i * 2;
}
</additional code>

- MHD_bin_to_hex uses a for loop: for (i = 0; i < size; ++i). The controlling expression i < size depends on the loop variable i and the parameter size, so it is not invariant. There are no do-while or while loops with constant conditions, nor any other constant controlling expressions.

- Other expressions (ternary ?:, assignments, bitwise ops) are not loop/selection controlling expressions and thus are not relevant to Rule 14.3.
